comments.text:
Look into Soft Paws. (I don't work for the company -- I swear!!) 

When the SPCA was convincing me not to de-claw my newly adopted kitten 
(thank goodness for that!), they referred me to Soft Paws, which are little 
plastic caps that go on the kitty's claws. They don't hurt the cat (which 
is why SPCA recommends) but because they're covering the claw in dull 
plastic, the cat won't hurt anything when they scratch. I looked into it to 
keep my kitty from wrecking furniture (in the end she was easily trainable) 
but in your case, it could protect the elders!

comments.text:
+Ela Mongrella yes but honestly... to those people who are more worried 
about a piece of REPLACEABLE furniture... than they are the health, 
happiness and safety of their pets, WAKE UP! if you take on the 
responsibility to bring a pet into your home you better be ready and 
willing to do what it takes, yes even getting over laziness and capping 
some claws, in order to ensure ALL family members are happy and healthy. 
cats and dogs are not a commodity, they are not just there to be pretty to 
look at, they are here to join in peace and love with their masters and it 
is our responsibility to show them the same respect. they entrusted their 
lives to us, please dont be materialistic peeps. Also, i do recommend 
buying an actual animal trimmer to clip their clazws with if clipping is 
your choice. the reasoning i tell people not to use human nail clippers is 
the simple difference in anatomy between our nails and a cats nails. theirs 
are in a round and pointed structure, where as ours are flat. hence the 
difference in clippers. there is a good reason for this. to be honest i 
worked in an animal shelter and had seen plenty of cats come in with split, 
embedded, and curling nails and the explanation the owners gave us for 
dumping them at the shelter was it was too much work to get them to sit 
still for their clippings. well duh, you were hurting their paws and we 
sent them home with calming paw gel they lick off and a real set of animal 
clippers and usually didnt see the cat get dropped back off to us.
comments.author: Shayna Marie

replace your own fake nails every so often because they break down. i clip 
both of my cats claws. but i did use soft paws on them as kittens when the 
scratching instinct is strongest. you can not expect to put caps on nails 
that GROW and never have them come off. if they do not come off when they 
are supposed to, it can pose a health risk for the cat. again, as i always 
say, if you are going to welcome pets into your home and into your family, 
be ready and willing to do a little work to keep them safe, happy, and 
healthy, the same as you would a child in your care. they did not choose to 
be brought into your home, it is your responsibility to treat them with 
respect.

comments.text:
scratching does not make the nails blunt! Please do not spew wrong 
information! One of the reasons cats scratch is to help shed the outer 
(dull blunt) sheath exposing new very sharp claws. If you've ever seen cats 
nails that do not scratch you would know what i'm talking about. Their 
nails are very dull and not healthy looking. If you look around the floor 
where cats usually scratch you can find that outer sheath shed off a lot 
like a snake skin.

My mom still declaws her cats, and I don't know how to change her mind... 
In the past two weeks, she turned down the adoption of a pair of cats 
simply because their current owner didn't, and rightfully so, want the cats 
to be declawed. 
I didn't realize it when I was a kid, but she adopted a kitten with her 
claws still in when we were young, and she got the kitten declawed a short 
time after that. The cat turned very mean, and my mom gave her back to the 
shelter. And I didn't know that that change in behavior was largely due to 
having been declawed. Understandably so; she got her knuckles removed! 
When I get my own place and can adopt my own cat, I won't get him or her 
declawed, but I don't know how to convince my mom not to get any more / 
declaw any more cats...﻿

comments.text:
A few years back after moving into a new duplex an orange tabby started 
hanging around me and I could tell it was less than a year old.  When I 
finally sat down on the porch for her to come up to me, she ignored my dog, 
I could tell she had been declawed and she still had a stitch in her belly 
from being spayed.  To the others around me she was mean.  She bit quite a 
bit.  I worked with her and she trusted me.  She did get to where she would 
lay on someones lap without being hurting them.  They could pet here but 
only a couple times so most times people would just pet her once and leave 
her be as she slept on their laps.  I figured she 'ran away' from her home 
because of the declawing and pain she had endured.  I'm very happy she 
found me because I gave her the love and time to learn to be around me and 
others without striking back.  I named her:  Sassy, the Cuddly Evil. :)  
Very fitting for when she first came to me but she was a very loving cat 
after a couple months.  So, yes to your statement Aviarmew, I believe the 
cat became mean after enduring all that pain caused by the declawing.  I 
don't really blame her.

comments.text:
Remember that these are miniature predators and tree climpers so getting 
ways for your cat to get high and putting carpets in places where they can 
scratch without damaging stuff is good the claws are sharpened and 
otherwise maintained when the cat uses them against things like trees in 
the wild. As well as marking their turf with scent from the corner of their 
mouths a lot of cats have scent glands in their feet if I remember 
correctly. So given enough productive scratching spaces you shouldn't have 
to rip your cats finger tips off. The very tips, just like with humans has 
no feeling and just like if you cut back your fingernail too far, it will 
sting and bleed. But there is a slight difference in the coloration to 
watch out for and the blood vessels are visible and they make tools to help 
gauge the trimming

+scarlett wing I'm sorry, but cat's claws still need to be clipped if they 
don't use appropiate surfaces to keep them at a reasonable length. Simply 
applying caps means the claws will keep growing with the result that simply 
walking around will become uncomfortable for the cat. I've never seen a cat 
grow skin over enough of it's claws that they can't be painlessly trimmed 
and if I did I'd take it straight to a vet.

comments.text:
+Sveinn Faltskog Sveinn, I am not defending declawing, by any means. I 
personally do not agree with it as there are other solutions, such as 
training or claw caps, that work effectively to solve problem scratching. 
This is something I *always* work on training with cats in the shelter, 
because it is a big issue for many owners. I have even offered training to 
several adopters after the cats are in their new home to make sure they 
were successful. You would not believe how many cats are turned into 
shelters daily for destructive clawing. Or they are just dumped off (we get 
lots of this where I live in the country). However, if it comes down to 
declawing with a good home versus death in a shelter... I'm sorry but I 
have to choose life. And, unfortunately, that is what it comes down to for 
many cats. :( That is my only point.

Most shelters do take very good care of the animals in their custody. The 
employees and volunteers are generally all animal lovers and will do 
whatever they can to make these animals lives better and get them a home. 
However, with the sheer volume of animals turned in each day, it is a 
nearly impossible task. But, we always do our very best to get as many 
animals adopted successfully (as in they do not get turned back in to 
shelters) as possible. I do not think the overpopulation issue is as bad in 
the countries you mentioned. Close to 4 million pets are killed every year 
because of this epidemic. There is no way to house them all - and, sadly, 
it isn't much of a life for them living in a tiny cage. There are simply 
too many people irresponsibly allowing their pets to breed.

comments.text:
Wow, you all are aggressive in attacking someone who doesn't believe the 
same things you do. Do you really think this is the best approach to help 
someone learn the truth about declawing? Or to see the errors in their 
thought process on it?

As I have said in numerous comments, normally I do not agree with 
declawing, as I think alternatives should be exhausted before even 
considering it. However, under certain circumstances, I can't really be 
whole-heartedly against it either. Let me try to explain. I volunteer in 
both a kill shelter and a non-kill shelter. Both are packed well past 
capacity with cats. A very low percentage of these babies ever get a chance 
at a new home; there are simply not enough people who care. Those who do 
are generally looking for a kitten or very young adult under the age of 1 
or 2. The older cats just can't catch a break. One of the things I do is 
train cats on the basics (litter box, sitting, playing politely with other 
cats, leash training, grooming, and general manners) to make them more 
attractive to adopters. Problem is, we don't get enough people in to adopt 
all of them, no matter what we do to improve their chances. Furthermore, 
one of the biggest reasons cats are dumped at our shelters is scratching 
and destroying someone's home.

In the no-kill shelter, we have cats that have been there for years. It is 
an opened space area so they are not constantly in cages, thankfully, but 
it is so sad to see them get passed over again and again. They have a 
forever home at the shelter but that is really no life for a cat. In the 
kill shelter, we have cats that have been there much longer than they 
normally would be, thanks to my pleading and begging. But that can only go 
so far when there is nowhere to house them. Cats are still routinely killed 
every week! We can't even get a decent amount of people to foster... let 
alone adopt. This is an epidemic on a national level in the United States - 
not just my area. I live in a small rural town so I can imagine what the 
big city shelters' see. So, this is where I have trouble with this topic. 
Is it fair to leave a cat in a shelter environment, knowing that it will be 
killed, when it could be spoiled in a loving home? I'm sorry, but if it 
means a cat will be declawed, but have a good forever home, I cannot be 
against that. The life and treatment of the cat are more important. Would 
you prefer they be killed? Yes, it is horribly tragic to have to choose 
between the two, but sadly it is a reality we face currently.

Personally, I have a cat with epilepsy, which is controlled with daily 
medication. She is not a lap cat at all and does not like to be restrained 
in any manner (which we have to do to get the medicine down her throat - 
she doesn't like any food but her dry food - no treats, soft food, or even 
tuna - so we can't sneak it into a treat), it scares her, so sometimes she 
sinks in her claws. I let her do it, it doesn't matter if she hurts me, as 
long as it makes her feel safe, secure, and helps her take the medicine she 
needs. I am usually covered in scratches from her but that's okay. The 
point is, it isn't something I take lightly or would agree with for 
convenience only.
comments.author: Snow Lynx

I have to say I disagree. I have had my kitties declawed to prevent 
scratched on my little ones and the furniture. They are strictly inside

have nothing to fight for. One passed due to the food poisoning in 2008. I 
now have another. I only have one. When they are declawed, any vet will 
tell you to buy newspaper litter to prevent pain on their paws when they 
need to go to the bathroom. I have never had any issues. My cat is safe, 
happy, and a great loving family member. I had his done when he was 10 
weeks old. I doubt at 3 years old he even remembers having them.
He still bats at us to play, he still walks fine, he still jumps around. It 
isn't this horrid thing that some would have you believe. I have never had 
an issue. But, again, my cat is my baby, and he does not go outside. Ever. 
He has his home and lots of love and cat nip. The vet we go to is 
wonderful. My kitty spent a week in bed with me so I knew he wouldn't hurt 
himself. He was too little to want to jump off of our bed since it sits 
high. He also is neutered. I wonder if that is inhumane too? I had him 
neutered because there is less territory issues with him being neutered. We 
also have a bunny. Hence, no claws. The bunny is never let on the floor 
with the kitty because the kitty isn't sure yet he belongs. LOL! That is 
our new addition. I take him out and play and cuddle. Happy bunny, happy 
kitty. Sometimes, you need to know the other side. It isn't nearly as awful

comments.text:
+Felix Ray Alright, man. I'm glad we can disagree without acting like 
idiots, and I am not a fan of hyperbole or hysterics either.  I am usually 
an opponent of moral crusaders. People get totally worked up about a 
cause, which I feel is understandable in this case, but the way they go 
about it only puts people off, which is counter-intuitive. This is what I 
would say to someone who believes that cats can be declawed, and that many 
of them will suffer little to no long-term impacts on their lives. Cats 
are part of a group of animals known as digitigrades. This word comes from 
Latin, and it means "toe-walker." They walk on their digits, or toes. In 
the case of cats, they walk with over 60% of their weight on that end bone 
which is amputated during a declaw procedure. This forces them to shift 
their weight to the back of their paw, which is an unnatural way for them 
to walk. It can cause arthritis, and several other problems. In many cases, 
the bone grows back, but in pieces or chips. This is extremely painful for 
cats, as the sharp pieces cut into surrounding tissue. As it is essentially 
a foreign object, the bone pieces will become infected and surrounded by 
pus, which makes its way into the bloodstream of the cat, causing liver and 
kidney damage. I'm glad you don't declaw your cats, but you should really 
tell other that it's wrong. Diabetes and being prone to infection is 
absolutely no excuse to declaw a cat, because all you're doing is making 
the cat more likely to bite. Bites are more likely to cause infection than 
a scratch, and furthermore, increased aggression is a side-effect of 
declawing. If anything, someone with a compromised immune system has even 
MORE reason to keep the cat's claws intact. They can also clip the cat's 
nails, and even cover them with soft caps if they want. As Jackson Galaxy 
said, there is no reason to declaw a cat, ever. It is never in the interest 
of the cat to declaw, and there is always a solution to whatever problem 
arises from the claws that can be implemented without declawing. There's 
always a better solution.
comments.author: Ryan117S

comments.text:
You have no idea what you're talking about. Millions of dogs and cats are 
euthanized because there are too many without homes. Spaying and neutering 
is done to prevent more homeless animals from being born into a life of 
needless suffering. It's called stopping a problem before it starts. 
Declawing means you are amputating ten or twenty separate limbs from a cat. 
That's what it is, amputation, at least ten limbs cut off. A dog or cat can 
still live a happy, pain-free life after being spayed/neutered. Cats are 
often severely traumatized by declawing, with a range of post-operative 
complications including behavior issues like refusing to use the litter box 
because it hurts their wounded feet, and increased biting. There is a high 
risk of infection, because the amputation wounds frequently re-open. Once 
declawed, a cat is robbed of its primary means of defense, and its only 
means of escape from predators. They use their claws to defend themselves 
when attacked, and this buys them that split-second they need to run away, 
usually at which point their instincts tell them to climb a tree or a fence 
to escape. Without front claws, they can't climb at all. You should also 
type the words "phantom limb pain" into Google, and see what comes up. Cats 
undoubtedly suffer from phantom limb pain, as human amputees do, but they 
can't tell us that. Declawing is far more cruel than spaying/neutering, 
trust me. There are multiple alternatives to declawing. As Jackson Galaxy 
said, declawing almost NEVER has to happen. There is one rare condition in 
which a cat will develop tumors on or near that terminal limb, and the only 
thing we can do, for now, is to amputate, but that's a very, very rare 
condition, and even then, only the affected toes are amputated. That is the 
only legitimate medical reason to declaw a cat. Otherwise, it's not 
necessary. This campaign is not about shaming people, it's about educating 
people, so they know what declawing really entails. If you didn't know what 
it really was before, and your veterinarian possibly misled you, or didn't 
give you all the information, then you just didn't know. You can't change 
the past, but now that you do know, you can make sure you never do it 
again. You can also tell others about what it really is. Once you know more 
about declawing, if you're still okay with it, that says something pretty 
bad about you, about your moral character.
comments.author: Ryan117S

comments.text:
The problem is the declawing in and of itself can CAUSE future problems. A 
kitten may bounce back from the initial surgery a bit quicker than an adult 
or older cat, but they aren't spared from anything else. Without the claws, 
the cats may honestly feel even less secure (they feel defenseless), and 
the fighting may very well intensify. A cat that doesn't feel comfortable 
in itself and its environment will usually be much quicker to lash out. A 
cat in pain will almost always be quicker to lash out. Biting can be just 
as nasty, or even more so, than scratch marks.

When he was talking about it changing their physiology, it changes the 
entire way their body supports weight. Rather than being up on tip-toe as 
they are supposed to be, it forces them to stand slightly farther back than 
is normal. I don't know if you know much about horses or any hoofed 
animals, but it's similar to overgrown hooves forcing horses to stand in 
unnatural positions, and eventually rendering them lame. It places stress 
on areas of the joints that aren't mean to handle it. Sure, it may not be 
too bad once they adjust to it initially, but as they get older, years upon 
years of unnatural positions WILL cause severe discomfort and pain, usually 
in the shoulders, hips, elbows, knees, wrists, and/or ankles. Arthritis 
usually sets in faster, and more severely in declawed cats. The problem is 
compounded by the fact that scratching things with their claws actually 
exercises the muscles in the paws and legs. A full bodied, luxurious 
scratch even more so. Without the exercise of normal scratching, the 
muscles will weaken just the same as any other muscle.

There's risks in having the surgery done in and of itself, as with any 
major surgery. Admittedly a smaller risk, but a risk all the same, is that 
with one small slip of the hand, one little mistake during the surgery, the 
veterinarian could potentially make the cat completely lame in that paw. It 
isn't common, but not completely unheard of for a vet to make a mistake and 
basically ruin the entire paw. It doesn't take much. An infection setting 
in after the surgery can be a risk to the cat's paw, leg, and even 
life-threatening if it progressed far enough.

I hope this doesn't seem offensive, but in my opinion declawing is just 
another way for saying "I don't want to fix the actual issue at hand. I 
would rather mutilate and (again in my unforgiving opinion) essentially 
physically and mentally torture my cat than work through an issue." To me, 
it sounds as though you need to be working on getting the two cats to get 
along. I would highly recommend watching some of Jackson's My Cat From Hell 
episodes. He gives many wonderful tips to helping two cats get along 
better. Try some of them out, any of them, until you find something that 
works for your cats. If you can help the cats co-exist, then the need for 
declawing is null. Your cats will be a thousand times happier, you'll be 
happier, and on the bright side of it, you'll save money and the torment of 
watching the cats in extreme pain after the surgery when they're too sore 
to even stand, and the frustration when it doesn't fix a single thing, or 
possibly even makes things worse. Declawing is not reversible. Please don't 
do something that you, and your cats, will regret for the rest of their 
lives.

comments.text:
No, what you said is: "If you don't wanna get scratched then don't get 
close enough its that simple." So, yes,you did say not to touch your cat. 
So, I'm sorry, but that is a ridiculous statement.

All cats need touch of some sort of touch unless they have reverted back to 
a wild, or feral, state. But, even then, cats want to be touched, they are 
just afraid of it. However, I do agree that not all cats are lap cats. My 
Persian, for example, hates to be held or restrained. He has hated it since 
he was a tiny kitten. He is very loving otherwise and loves full body 
massages. So, I agree to his terms on that and don't do what he dislikes. 
Any relationship with an animal, of any kind, needs to be on their terms.

I strongly disagree that a person does only gets scratched when they push 
things too far. You can get them in multiple ways that are unintentional; 
for instance, by a cat jumping off your lap, a cat playing too rough, and 
many other ways.

I am not pro-declawing, by any means, yet I am not fully against it either. 
One of the shelters I volunteer at is a kill shelter. I see cats turned in 
everyday for scratching issues. Unfortunately, our take-in rate is much 
lower than the adoption rate, so cats with these types of issues are often 
euthanized. So, in many ways, it becomes a question of whether you would 
rather see a cat declawed or dead. That is the reality I live in and I 
think life is more valuable.

+Abram Ke As far as the question "is there something wrong with spaying and 
neutering of animals?" then yes, this is a topic worth talking about. But 
as far as de-clawing and spaying/neutering being equally wrong, I don't see 
how the two are comparable at all. First of all, de-clawing directly 
impacts the quality of life for a cat, whereas the spaying and neutering of 
an animal, as far as short term physiological and psychological effects 
goes, only stops their yearning for genetic propagation and the obvious 
ability to do so. It's definitely a topic for discussion, but comparing 
de-clawing to spaying/neutering can both downplay how destructive 
de-clawing can be, and makes spaying and neutering seem equally deplorable 
as de-clawing.

Personally, I have found Soft Paws to be a great solution to scratching. 
Only drawback with those, however, is they don't last more than a few weeks 
(4 to 6 typically) so it could get expensive long-term. Not that I am 
saying that excuses declawing, by any means, but it wouldn't be an option 
for every cat owner to use them.

For example, one pack of 40 costs around $13, which would last for 2 
applications. Now, I have 3 cats currently, so it would cost me around $39 
every 2 months or so. Now, I wouldn't have a problem with that, but many 
people just couldn't realistically  afford it. Many also have far more than 
3 cats as well. In my area, a declaw costs between $100 to $120, which 
comes out to considerably less overall. Sadly, a lot of people will grab 
the one that is easiest and cheapest without much thought. That is the only 
issues I have with them.

how many cats get put down each year). Neutering helps cats stay in homes.

life.

+Lannie90210 I didn't really intend to get a cat, she was a kitten and I

dog and cat made a bond and they became best friends. We soon discovered my 
cat had separation anxiety when someone tried to adopt the kitten. It 
wasn't good for her health to keep them apart so I decided to keep the cat. 
Soon after, however, my cat began to claw my dog when they played together. 
She would use her claws to get on top of my dog and my dog got an infection 
on her muzzle from a cat scratch mark. We tried trimming her nails, nail 
caps, and training but none of that worked. (We needed a quick solution to 
prevent my dog from getting a serious injury. The longer it took the more 
likely my dog was going to get hurt.) We tried to re-home my cat, but she 
still had separation anxiety. Then we decided to get her claws removed for 
her benefit and my dogs. It was the best option for both of them, and now 
they live together happily and my cat no longer has separation anxiety.

comments.text: HA! but cutting off toes isn't? Right. Get your priorities straight please!
comments.author: Kiersten Greenwood

comments.text: Spraying her with water? That's real animal abuse in my mind.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
YOU are the stupid one. Just because a pet, that YOU decide to take the 
responsibility of having gives you trouble doesn't mean you give up and 
take the easy way! You know what i would do?! I would never have taken away 
the cats claws and continued to spray her with water everytime she got 
rough with the dog or kept them seperate when i wasn't there, and don't 
give me the darn anxiety speech having anxiety is much less worse than 
having your toes cut off. I would give the cat exercise everyday and extra 
scratching posts. Having a pet takes dedication and commitment. I 
definitely would have continued to train her even if if wouldnt ever be 
completely successful. And i know you're going to give me a bunch of 
excuses why you couldn't well, if you dont have time to train an animal 
then you shouldnt have one. Now, I'm officially done responding.
comments.author: Kiersten Greenwood

comments.text:
And, by the way, knowing you you will probably just state something along 
the lines "Declawing is wrong, you are a bad person, blah blah blah." or 
something else completely irrelevant to the response I just gave you.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
Are you honestly that *stupid*? Never once in awnswer to your pathetic 
comments did I state that I agree with declawing. I was just simply stating 
that I personally have seen no health defects from it. *I DO NOT AGREE WITH 
DECLAWING* Yes, I did declaw my cat, but that does not mean you should 
declaw yours. There was a reason I declawed my cat, and if you can't get 
that through your tiny, immature brain, I think it should be me refusing to 
talk to you. I already read every shitty little comment you posted and not 
ONCE did you offer me another solution to the problem I described besides 
soft paws, and newsflash, THEY DIDN'T WORK! So for the *5th* time:

*WHAT WOULD YOU HAVE DONE!?*

If you cannot give me an answer to that simple question, I will just have 
to accept the fact that you are the most idiotic person I have met and 
choose not to waste my time explaining myself over and over again just to 
be insulted. I refuse to talk to people who are so stupid it hurts, and you 
may just be one of those people.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text:
You know what, I'm done talking to you. I'm done talking to people who 
refuse to learn or understand that declawing an innocent animal is wrong! 
I'll keep your cat in my mind and hope she doesn't develop terrible 
arthritis and that you guys won't just take the easy way out if she has any 
future problems...
comments.author: Kiersten Greenwood

comments.text:
Tell me then what would you have done in my situation, we couldn't just 
allow her to severely injure my dog. If you can tell me an option other 
than soft paws, nail trimming, training, or declawing,I would really like 
to know.
comments.author: Keightley P

comments.text: i read them, but i still would never declaw my cat.
comments.author: Kiersten Greenwood

comments.text:
I read everything you wrote and I've *already* responded that we tried soft 
paws, we tried training her, we tried trimming her nails, nothing worked. 
Apparently it was you who chose not to read my comments. +Kiersten Greenwood
comments.author: Keightley P

top_comment.text:
WTF I always thought declawing was no big deal because I just thought it 
was a fancy word for cutting/trimming their claws down a little with 
scissors (the way to do it if you're normal)...DA FUQ is this shit!?!? 
Animal abuse makes you no better than muslims!!!﻿
top_comment.author: wazzobazzo

comments.text:
+Yukki Katsuki"So obviously the first thing to do when your cat starts 
scratching things is declaw them"

No then the first thing you do is not get a cat at all and get a fishtank 
instead (fishes don't have claws). You wouldn't remove a dog's 
teeth because it happened to chew on your shoes...

A little scratched furniture is nothing compared to muslim level animal 
abuse. Fuck this shit!
comments.author: wazzobazzo

comments.text:
The reason it can't jut be trimmed down to bone is because a cats claw will 
grow back time and time again unless the root of the claw which is 
basically imbedded within the knuckles is destroyed. So obviously the first 
thing to do when your cat starts scratching things is declaw them why would 
u even think about getting scratching furniture or trimming there nails.
comments.author: Yukki Katsuki

top_comment.text: Isn't getting a cat neutered an even more invasive surgery though?﻿
top_comment.author: smof1

comments.text:
I wish I could have stopped my folks from declawing my three cats but it's 
too late now :( Is there anything I can do to make their lives better now? 
They seem happy
comments.author: smof1

comments.text:
It's not about the invasiveness of the surgery, but how it affects the cats 
both immediately afterwards and for the rest of their lives. I've had cats 
all my life and after neutering surgery (especially with the advances in 
veterinary anaesthesia of the past few years) they return home as if 
nothing has happened. Both males and females have just a 1cm incision and 
by the time the pain relief has worn off there is no pain - and no unwanted 
kittens. Neutered cats also have longer life expectancies. A de-clawed cat 
is not just inconvenienced for a couple of days like a cat being neutered, 
it is mutilated and suffers for the rest of its life - no defence, no way 
to escape, altered gait and its associated problems and unable to even 
scratch an itch. How can anyone even consider it?
comments.author: Snowleopard755

comments.text:
Cats don't normally put their entire body weight on their "privates". 
Imagine having your toenails ripped out and told to walk on your feet. When 
a cat wakes up after surgery they are groggy and try to get up. They don't 
understand they are drugged but it is instinct to be alert and aware so 
they try to stand up and BAM..pain. If you've ever seen a cat wake up after 
a declawing you would understand. Every time they put weight on their feet 
they meow with pain.
comments.author: Kchimobella

comments.text:
+smof1 Thanks for your reply! We will try to answer your question in the 
hangout tomorrow if there's time!
comments.author: Jackson Galaxy

comments.text:
I do appreciate that you want to address the question. Unfortunately that 
time for me likely won't work. I could probably do it any other day except 
tomorrow if possible. If not I understand but please do address the 
question if you can either way.
comments.author: smof1

comments.text:
Hey there Smof! Jackson's team has presented your question to The Cat Daddy 
himself, and he has agreed to address it specifically, in the Google+ 
Hangout happening LIVE tomorrow Wed. Feb. 5 at 3:30 p.m. Pacific time at 
http://anmlst.co/JacksonGalaxyHangout. Can you join us in the Hangout 
tomorrow to ask Jackson your question live on air? Reply to this comment 
and we'll send you a direct message with more info!
comments.author: Jackson Galaxy

comments.text:
Also, as far as spaying, it can help prevent certain cancers. Heat cycles 
also can't be comfortable.
comments.author: Ashley Holmes

comments.text:
not even close. the cat never misses what it lost once it heals from a spay 
or neuter surgery. Cats that are declawed have pain and discomfort for the 
rest of their lives. How would you like to have all of the tips of your 
fingers removed and then have to walk on them every day?
comments.author: Julie Vaughn

comments.text:
How on earth could you think that?  Spaying and neutering is the best way 
way to control over population.  Declawing is for people who think it stops 
cats clawing up their stuff.  If you give your cats the right toys and 
exercise they don't claw your stuff.
comments.author: Net Ward

comments.text:
No, especially for the males. There are so many strays and unwanted cats 
filling the shelters, it is cruel not to neuter your cat. I have always had 
my cats neutered as soon as I could. Male and female recover very quickly. 
I noticed my females has less discomfort than the males did. Their 
discomfort only lasted a couple of days, the females didn't seem to have 
any discomfort.
comments.author: chanah wizenberg

top_comment.text:
my cat was done 5 years ago and he is still sore so do not de claw your cat 
and my cat still has the knuckle they took out the nail  only ﻿
top_comment.author: Diane Rochon

comments.text:
liesss... if they ONLY remove the claw - it will still grow back. One of my 
cat's nails was forcefully removed and it grew back about 2 month later. 
You have to remove the nail matrix, which is on the last phalanges 
(knuckle) otherwise it will continue to grow back.
comments.author: mizzu M

comments.text: and yes i went to the vet for it
comments.author: Diane Rochon

captions.text: Today it comes out.

In no uncertain terms, by
the time we're done today,

you will know exactly
where the cat daddy stands.

People, let's talk
about declawing.
It's very simple.

I mean, declawing is something
that I come across every day.

25% of all cats in
the US are declawed,
which is crazy when you ask me.
Why is it crazy?

Because declawing is,
in my humble opinion,

inhumane, barbaric, for
the most part cosmetic,
and it is unnecessary.
What is declawing?

Declawing is actually
de-knuckling.

You think that all you're
doing is pulling out

the claws of a cat to make
your belongings safer,
or your kids, or you.
But it's not.

It is the amputation
of the first joint

of every knuckle
on a cat's paws.
I'm here to talk for the cats.

And the cats say,
of course I wouldn't
want my knuckles amputated.
And for what reason?

We're removing the initial
line of defense for a cat.

When a cat tries to get your
attention because they don't

like what's going
on, then they're
going to pat pat at you.

If you don't get that message,
then the claws come out.

Hey, I'm trying to
tell you something.

And the third line of
defense is their teeth.
That's when they bite.

So when a cat gets
their claws taken away

because you think you're
going to be safer,
I'm telling you what.

You're going to get bit
more often than not.

Cats who are declawed
are more likely to get
surrendered to shelters.
Why is that?

Usually because of
secondary symptoms,

a cat goes in the litter box for
the first time after surgery.
It hurts.

A cat doesn't say,
wow, my paws hurt.

What they say when they
step in the litter box
is that place hurts.
And why would I go back there?

Yeah, no reasonable
cat would go back
into something that hurts them.
So they stop.

And cats who are
declawed then wind up
with litter box problems.
That's when I meet them.

Let's also talk about what we're
doing to a cat's physiology.
We are changing it.

Cats are what we
call digitigrade.
They walk on their tiptoes.

And when we change the
formation of their paws, poot,
they sink down.
Please, think about it.

Later on in life, are they
more susceptible to arthritis,
for instance?

Of course they
are, because we've

changed the way
nature made them.

Now, do cats who
suffer declawing

have problems
defending themselves?
Sure they do.

Declawed cats have a
hard time climbing trees
to get away from predators.

Even though vets
are still performing

declawing to a large
degree, they'll

still say, keep
your cat indoors,

because they have trouble
defending themselves outdoors.

Is declining with
a laser better?

It's less messy,
sure, but there have

been papers published that
say that there is absolutely

no correlation between
laser declawing

and a decrease in the amount
of chronic pain and discomfort

that a cat will experience,
none whatsoever.

Declawing is so
predictably painful

that pharmaceuticals
actually use it

as a measure to test
pain medication.

Guys, 22 countries
on record, and I'm

sure more at this
point, have banned
declawing, whole countries.

Now, we've been
fighting in the States

to ban it city by city
because of some arcane laws

that prevent us from going
after the states, at least

in California, but entire
countries, 22 of them.

Well, the one thing
I don't want to do

is come across as
somebody who is

wagging their
finger at everybody.
That's not who I am.
I swear to you.

I'm an educator and a
student for the most part.

But I'm here to tell you
that it's forgivable.

If you said, oh, my
grandparents declawed.

My mom declawed her
cats, so I declawed mine.

It's fine if you're
learning right now.

If you refuse to look at
both anecdotal and scientific

evidence and you don't
listen to me, someone

who has been in the field for 20
years working with these cats,

then I have a hard time
forgiving, because you

are going against what
you know about your cats.

If you want to learn more about
declawing, well, first of all
there's me.

And you will find articles
on cats, scratching,

and how cats can live happily
ever after on my website.

As a matter of fact, you
probably see a link for it
right there.

But also another link right
there would be pawproject.org.

Man, you got lots of
great information there.

But here, this is what
I'm going to be doing.
I'll be giving away two.

Count them, two copies
of The Paw Project movie.

I will autograph it, sign it
to you, or your favorite cat,

or someone that you're
trying to educate.

I'll sign their name
right on here as well.
And it is a fantastic movie.
So stay tuned, guys.

All you've got do is leave
a comment on the bottom

of this here page,
subscribe to this channel,

and you are entered
automatically
to win one of these movies.

And hurry up, because you only
have a short amount of time
to do this.

More information to
follow, so please subscribe
and you'll find out more.

title: Declawing: Jackson Galaxy Just Says No!
